l2item.para: Characters are produced by applying, by any means, an ink which does not injure the surface. Inks used in marking may have a light etching action, providing etching does not damage the surface.

note.para: Ordinarily, ink stamping and electrolytic etching, when used as a temporary marking method, may be applied to any surface which, after assembly, does not move relative to a contacting surface.

l1item.para: Marking Materials, Hot and Cold Section Engine Parts

l2item.para: (PWC05-048A)Felt Wick Pen and (PWC05-046)Speedry Instant Dry Ink.
(PWC05-048)Brushpen No. 57 and (PWC05-046A)Tex-Rite Instant Dry Ink.
(PWC05-002)Micro Supreme No. 142 (Purple Dye) .
(PWC05-103)Phano No. 71 Red Pencil. May be used on parts which are not directly exposed to the gas path. This type of mark is easily obliterated and, therefore, less durable.
(PWC05-018A)Eberhard Faber Colorbrite Silver No. 2101, or Joseph Dixon Best Silver No. 1936 pencils .

l1item.para: Marking Materials, Cold Section Engine Parts Only

Marking Materials, Hot Section Engine Parts Only. Use layout dye (lightly applied) to mark parts which are directly exposed to engine gas path such as turbine blades and disks, turbine vanes, and combustion chamber liner.

caution.para: APPLICATION OF LUBRICANT PLUS PROPER ASSEMBLY, WILL PREVENT DAMAGE TO PACKINGS WHICH COULD CAUSE ENGINE MALFUNCTION.

l1item.para: Prior to installation, new o-ring type preformed packings must be coated with a thin film of (PWC03-001)engine oil unless otherwise specified.

title.xref: Torque Check for Reuse of Self-Locking Nuts, Bolts and Helical Coil Inserts (Pound-inches at Room Temperature and Lubricated With Engine Oil)
Locking Torque for Self-locking Nuts and Helical Coil Inserts
Safety Cable Minimum Crimp Requirements (Pull-off Load)

caution.para: DUST CAPS USED TO PROTECT OPEN TUBES AGAINST CONTAMINATION SHALL ALWAYS BE INSTALLED OVER THE TUBE ENDS AND NOT IN THE TUBE ENDS. FLOW THROUGH THE LINES MAY BE BLOCKED OFF IF LINES ARE INADVERTENTLY INSTALLED WITH DUST CAPS IN THE TUBE ENDS.
TOOL SURFACES WHICH MAY CONTACT ENGINE CRITICAL AREAS MUST BE ADEQUATELY COVERED WITH A PROTECTIVE MATERIAL.

INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS OVER THE OUTSIDE OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS. DO NOT INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS ON THE INSIDE OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTOR SLEEVES. IMPROPER INSTALLATION OF CAP CAN DAMAGE THE INSIDE OF THE CONNECTOR.

l1item.para: To ensure proper reinstallation, tag and mark all parts, clips, and brackets as to their location.

During removal of tubes or engine parts look for indications of scoring, burning or other undesirable conditions. To facilitate reinstallation, observe the location of each part during removal. Tag unserviceable parts and units for investigation and possible repair.

Extreme care shall be taken to prevent dust, dirt, lockwire, nuts, washers or other foreign matter from entering the engine. It cannot be overemphasized that this precaution applies whenever work is done on the engine either on the wing or off the wing. Suitable plugs, caps, and other covering shall be used to protect all openings as they are exposed.

If at any time items are dropped into the engine, the assembly process must stop until the dropped articles are located, even though this may require a considerable amount of time and labor. Before assembling or installing any part, be sure it is thoroughly clean.

Lockwire, lockwashers, tablocks, tabwashers, or cotterpins must never be reused. All lockwire and cotterpins must fit snugly in holes drilled in studs and bolts for locking purposes. Install a cotterpin so that the head fits into the castellation of the nut, and unless otherwise specified, bend one end of the pin back over the stud or bolt and the other end down flat against the nut. Only lockwire and cotterpins made of corrosion resistant steel shall be used. Bushing plugs shall be lockwired to the assembly boss or case. Do not lockwire the plug to the bushing.
Replace all gaskets, packings, and rubber parts at reassembly. Make sure that new nonmetallic parts to be installed (such as an oil seal) show no sign of having deteriorated in storage.
To protect critical areas of engine parts (such as compressor and turbine disks) against scratches and nicks, tool surfaces contacting these areas must be covered with protective material.
When installing engine parts that require the use of a hammer to facilitate assembly or installation, use only a plastic or rawhide hammer.

Whenever adhesive tape has been applied to any part, the tape must be removed and the part thoroughly cleaned of all tape residue with petroleum solvent prior to being subjected to high temperature during engine run. Test results indicate that all tapes are capable of causing surface attack and/or reduction in tensile ductility as temperature increases. Do not leave tape or tape residue on engine parts.
If any part has been coated with corrosion preventive compounds, all traces of this compound and accumulated foreign matter must be removed.

taskproc.title: Removal of Straight Nipples, Straight Adapters, Bulkhead Couplings and Tube Connector Nipples

caution.para: DO NOT BEND, TWIST OR FORCE HYDRAULIC AND PNEUMATIC TUBES, WHETHER RIGID OR FLEXIBLE, TO ACHIEVE ALIGNMENT WITH MATING FITTING. ADJUST FITTING TO ALIGN WITH TUBE. CLAMP AND SECURE TUBE ONLY WHEN IT IS INSTALLED IN POSITION WITH NO NOTICEABLE TENSION OR LOAD.

l1item.para: Remove fittings from engine lines or accessory units.
Remove preformed packings from fittings and discard.

taskproc.title: Removal of Tube-to-Boss Elbows, Elbow Adapters and Elbow Assemblies

l1item.para: Remove fittings from engine lines or accessory units.

note.para: Before removal, mark angular position of fitting on engine or unit.

l1item.para: Remove preformed packings, packing retainers (back-up rings) and discard. Discard jam nuts from fittings.

taskproc.title: Installation of Straight Nipples, Straight Adapters, Bulkhead Couplings and Tube Connector Nipples

l1item.para: Lubricate new preformed packing with light film of ( PWC03-001)engine oil or fluid to be used in line.
Install preformed packing on fitting and screw fitting in boss or flange, as applicable.

caution.para: EXCESSIVE TIGHTENING WILL RESULT IN DAMAGE TO THREADS OF MATING PARTS.

l1item.para: Tighten fitting in boss and torque to value detailed in relevant assembly instruction.
Install jam nut on flange mounted fittings and torque jam nut to recommended value (Ref. Table .

taskproc.title: Installation of Tube-to-Boss Elbows, Elbow Adapters and Elbow Assemblies

l1item.para: Lubricate new preformed packings, packing retainer (back-up ring) and thread of elbow fitting with light film of (PWC06-002)petrolatum or fluid to be used in the line.
Assemble jam nut, new packing retainer and preformed packing on elbow fitting, pressing packing retainer into counterbore of jam nut.
Turn jam nut down elbow fitting until preformed packing is seated in non-threaded annulus of fitting.
Turn jam nut outward until preformed packing is pushed firmly against first lower thread of fitting.
Install elbow fitting into boss on unit, allowing jam nut to turn with fitting until preformed packing contacts boss mating face. This point will be recognized by increase in torque.
With fitting in this position, hold jam nut stationary and turn elbow fitting into boss a further 1 1/2 turns.

note.para: From this position the elbow fitting may be further turned inward to a maximum of one turn to facilitate alignment of fitting. Should the fitting tighten in the jam nut before completion of initial 1½ turns or during final alignment, the jam nut may be allowed to turn with the fitting for the remainder of the distance.

l1item.para: With elbow fitting in correct alignment position, tighten jam nut and torque to recommended torque (Ref. Table .

note.para: Metal-to-metal contact between jam nut and boss must be obtained without exceeding recommended torque and there must be no extrusion of preformed packing or packing retainer.

taskproc.title: Electrical Connectors

caution.para: INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS OVER THE OUTSIDE OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS. DO NOT INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS ON THE INSIDE OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTOR SLEEVES. IMPROPER INSTALLATION OF CAP CAN DAMAGE THE INSIDE OF THE CONNECTOR.

taskproc.para: Install protective plastic caps on all electrical connectors removed from components or engine (Ref. Fig. .

graphic.title: Installation of Protective Caps on Electrical Connectors

title.xref: Installation of Protective Caps on Electrical Connectors

l1item.para: A close and complete inspection is important to prolong engine life and give maximum performance. Check for loose or missing parts and inspect any engine part or component that has been worn or damaged. Damage to engine parts may result from improper clearance, lack of lubrication, undesired movement of parts which are bolted, pressed together, overloaded, uneven load distribution, heat, shock, extension of minor damage such as scratches, tool marks, grinding cracks, nicks, etc. Damage to engine parts may also result from presence of foreign matter such as grit, chips, moisture, chemicals, etc., or from incorrect techniques during removal and installation.

While it is frequently possible to repair a damaged part so that it may be safely reinstalled, it is important that the cause of the damage be determined and corrected if possible. Otherwise more serious consequences may result. Some of the physical conditions most commonly encountered during inspection of engine parts are listed in Table .
Inspect parts for alignment, distortion, foreign matter, looseness, out-of-roundness, sharp edges, scratches, taper, warping and wear. Additionally, check the following:

l2item.para: Holes in cases, manifolds, pipes and tubes for obstructions.
Gear tooth and splines for contact patterns.
Magnesium parts for corrosion.
Mounting pads, parting and seating surfaces, for smoothness and flatness. Use pencil carbon paper whenever a smear-type indication of surface smoothness is required.
Plugs for tightness.
Studs, dowels, and similar protruding parts for alignment and projection length.
Protective surface coatings for completeness.
Threads for condition.

note.para: When an inspection procedure requires a very accurate measurement, a micrometer, vernier caliper or a dial indicator must be used.

l1item.para: If a micrometer or vernier is to be used, check gage for accuracy before making measurement. Ensure that contacting surfaces are clean and contacting faces of part to be measured are free of dirt and burrs. When using depth gages, ensure anvil is held tight and square against part to be measured.
If a dial indicator is used, ensure indicator base is anchored firmly and that any swivel connections are tightened securely.
When taking measurements with feeler gages, ensure final size of feeler is a reasonably snug fit.

taskproc.title: Inspection of Fuel, Oil and Air Filters

l1item.para: When determining the condition of engine fuel, oil lubrication and pneumatic systems, removed filters must be inspected for condition, contamination and other defects before the application of any allowable cleaning procedures. Clogged filters could be cause for downstream low pressure in systems.

note.para: Other engine components will normally be cleaned prior to carrying out inspection procedure.

l1item.para: Inspect weld repair for quality, uniformity, undercutting, cracking and flux removal. Welds must be blended into adjacent metal in gradual, smooth curves. Welds must be sound, clean, free from foreign material, and from internal and external defects which would adversely affect strength of weld.
Nominal welds (those not requiring finishing) must exhibit bead conditions as shown in Figure , detail A. Finished welds must exhibit bead conditions as shown in detail B.

taskproc.title: Inspection of Fuel, Oil and Air Tubes

l1item.para: Cracks - Cracked tubing must be replaced. No repair is permitted.
Scratches - Minor scratches having no appreciable depth are acceptable. Scratches to a depth of 0.005 inch must be blended out. Replace tubing with scratches over 0.005 inch deep.

Nicks - Individual nicks up to 0.062 inch long by 0.010 inch wide and 0.003 inch deep can be ignored. Nicks to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch must be blended out to remove sharp edges. Replace tubing with nicks greater than 0.005 inch deep.

Dents - Round bottom dents on straight sections of tubing are permitted provided the length and depth are not greater than 10 percent of the normal outside diameter of tube. No more than one dent to maximum depth per 12 inch length of tube is acceptable. Dents on tube bends, which cause restriction by flattening and local weakening, are not acceptable.

Pitting - Minor isolated pitting up to 0.003 inch deep is acceptable. Clusters of pitting should be blended out to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch. Tubing must be replaced if pitting exceeds 0.005 inch deep.
Corrosion - Staining on tubing and surface corrosion is acceptable if removable by light polishing with crocus cloth and oil.

entry.para: A roughened area. Varying degrees of abrasion can be described as light or heavy depending upon the extent of repair necessary to restore the surface.
Presence of fine foreign material between moving surfaces.
General distortion in structure as distinguished from a local change in conformation such as a dent, peening, etc.
Forces as defined under STRESS, or uneven application of heat.
Raised areas indicating separation of the surface from the base. Usually found on plated or painted surfaces.
Imperfect bond with the base, usually aggravated by the presence of moisture.
Complete separation by force into two or more pieces.
Indentations sometimes found on the surface of ball or roller bearing parts.
Improper assembly or disassembly e.g. removing or installing a roller or ball bearing by force on the free race.
Injury to the surfaces by excessive heat. Evidenced by characteristic discoloration or, in severe cases, by loss or flow of material.
Excessive heat due to lack of lubrication, improper clearance.
Mechanical smoothing of a metal surface by rubbing not accompanied by removal of material but sometimes by discoloration around the outer edges of the area.
A sharp projection or rough edge.
Faulty machining operations, excessive wear, peening.
A rubbing action between two parts having limited relative motion.
Breaking out of small pieces of material.
Concentration of stress due to shock, nicks, scratches, inclusions, peening, etc., careless handling of parts.

Breakdown of the surface by chemical action. Metal deterioration resulting in a change of color and a rough surface, possibly associated with pits, which cannot be removed by light polishing with a crocus cloth. A distinction shall be made between corrosion and staining, which is associated with discoloration of a surface due to liquid drying on a part. Stains are considered acceptable as they have no measurable depth.
Excessive stress due to shock overloading, extension of a nick or scratch, or overheating.
Small, smoothly rounded hollow in the surface.
Concentrated overload resulting from peening or the pressure of chips between loaded surface; striking of part with dull object.
Breakdown of the surface by parts composed of sharp, minute indentations.
Carrying away of material by the flow of grit, chemicals, or hot gasses.
Flow of corroding liquids or grit-laden oils.

Progressive yielding of one or more local areas of weakness such as tool marks, cracks, or inclusions, under repeated stress. The progressive nature of the failure is usually indicated by several lines approximately concentric about a center, or “focus” which discloses the original point of failure.
Tool marks, sharp corners, nicks, cracks, inclusions, galling, corrosion, insufficient tightening of studs or bolts to obtain proper stretch.
Breaking away of pieces of a plated or painted surface.
Discoloration may occur on surfaces which are pressed or bolted together under high pressure. On steel parts the color is reddish brown. On aluminum the oxide is white.
Rubbing off in fine particles of metal slight movement between parts and subsequent oxidizing of these particles.
The transfer of metal from one surface to another.
Severe chafing or fretting action caused during engine operation by a slight relative movement of two surfaces under high contact pressure.
Development of a hard, glossy surface on bearing surfaces.
Combination of pressure oil and heat.
Displacement of material from a surface by a cutting, tearing or displacement effect.
Presence of a comparatively large foreign body between moving parts.
Smooth rounded furrows, such as score marks where sharp edges have been polished off.
Concentrated wear, abnormal relative motion of parts; parts out of alignment.
Enlargement of a crack or defect, burning of an exhaust flame.
Foreign material enclosed in the metal. Surface inclusions are indicated by dark spots or lines.
A sharp indentation caused by striking of one part against another metal object.
Carelessness in handling of parts or tools during, or prior to assembly; sand or fine foreign particles in the engine during operation.
Impact of foreign object, such as occurs in repeated blows of a hammer on the part.
Rolling up of metal, or transfer of metal from one surface to another.

Rubbing of two surfaces without sufficient lubrication; presence of grit between surfaces under pressure during assembly; unbroken edges of press fitted parts; incipient seizure of rotating parts during operations.
Displacement of particles of a surface from one point to another.

Small, irregularly shaped cavities in a surface from which material has been removed by corrosion or chipping. Corrosive pitting is usually accompanied by a deposit formed by the action of a corrosive agent on the base material.
Corrosive pitting; breakdown of the surface by oxidation or some other chemical or electrolytic action.
Deep scratches made by sharp edges of foreign particles during engine operation; elongated gouges.
Presence of chips between loaded surfaces having a relative motion.
Narrow, shallow marks caused by the movement of a sharp object or particles across a surface.
Carelessness in handling of parts or tools prior to, or during, assembly; sand or fine foreign particles in engine during operation.
Sharply roughened area characteristic of the progressive chipping or peeling of surface material.
Surface crack, inclusion or similar surface injury causing a progressive breaking away of the surface under load.
When used in describing the cause of failure of machine parts, stresses are generally divided into three groups - compression, tension and shear. These are used to describe the forces as follows:
COMPRESSION - Action of two directly opposed forces which tend to squeeze a part together.
TENSION - Action of two directly opposed forces which tend to pull apart.
SHEAR - Action between two opposed parallel forces.
External twisting opposed by shear stress.

warning.para: LIFE LIMITED (CRITICAL) ROTATING COMPONENTS EXHIBITING CRACKS ARE UNSERVICEABLE AND SHALL NOT BE REPAIRED.

caution.para: HANDLE ROTATING COMPONENTS WITH EXTREME CARE TO PREVENT DAMAGE OR CONTAMINATION OF THE MATERIAL.
WEAR LINT FREE GLOVES WHEN TOUCHING ROTATING COMPONENTS.
MAKE SURE CLOSE ATTENTION IS PAID TO AREAS SUCH AS COUNTERWEIGHT HOLES AND BLADE SLOTS WHERE IMPERFECTIONS ARE DIFFICULT TO FIND.
USE SUITABLE CLEAN, PROTECTIVE CONTAINERS FOR STORING AND TRANSPORTING COMPONENTS.

l1item.para: Inspect components in accordance with the criteria specified in the relevant Chapter/Section/Subject.
Any observed conditions not defined in this manual are not acceptable for repair.
Evaluation of the surface should take into consideration the need for repairs and the limits to which repairs may be made to determine the suitability for continued use of the component.
Unrepairable components shall be quarantined to prevent further use.
It is important to have suitable lighting. The minimum recommended illumination for close and difficult inspection is 100 foot-candles measured at the inspection table top.
Unless otherwise specified, magnification shall not be used. A magnification of 3 to 4X may be used as an aid to evaluate and confirm an observed condition in detail.
Gas turbine cleaning can be categorized into two broad areas, namely specific parts cleaning and field cleaning (i.e. compressor washing).

Specific parts cleaning is primarily to remove contaminants which might conceal minor cracks and other defects which, if not detected, could eventually lead to failure of a component or part. Engine components or parts should be cleaned only as necessary to perform required inspection and repair. Overcleaning of components or parts is unnecessary and should be avoided. The cleaning methods given in the following text are adequate for all maintenance levels. For compressor washing methods, refer to Task 71-00-00-160-801.
Prior to engine disassembly, ensure that the work area is clean.
Benches on which engine parts are placed must be clean and free from grit, metal fillings, etc., which may contaminate engine oil systems, fuel systems or hardware.
Clean plastic bags should be available in which oil system and fuel system parts may be stored until ready for reassembly.
Clean plastic caps or covers should be used to protect exposed tubes or bearing areas.
At reassembly ensure that all parts are clean and new packings installed.

caution.para: TAKE PARTICULAR CARE IN SELECTING CLEANING METHOD TO ENSURE THAT ANODIZING AND OTHER PROTECTIVE COATINGS ARE NOT REMOVED FROM PARENT METAL. DO NOT USE ALKALIES ON ALUMINUM, MAGNESIUM, ALUMINIZED AND PAINTED AREAS.

note.para: The choice of cleaning agents should be limited to consumables listed in INTRODUCTION. The toxicity of cleansing agent will, however, depend on the type of contamination encountered on part to be cleaned.

l1item.para: Wear rubber gloves, apron or coveralls and face shield or goggles, when working with solvents.
Use the least toxic of available cleaning materials which will satisfactorily accomplish work.
Perform all cleaning operations in a well ventilated work area.
Ensure that adequate and usable fire fighting and safety equipment is conveniently located and available to all personnel.
Do not smoke or expose a flame within 50 feet of cleaning area.
Do not use steel brushes for any cleaning operation except when specifically detailed within this manual. Use a stiff bristle fiber brush.

Surface to be welded must be free from protective coatings, dirt, grease, oil and other contaminants, and as free as practicable from oxide formation. Wire brushes and abrasives may be used to remove protective coatings and oxides, except that the final step in removing oxides from aluminum alloys preferably should consist of chemical treatment immediately prior to welding. Wire brushes, when used for cleaning corrosion-resistant alloy, must have bristles of austenitic, corrosion-resistant steel. No undesirable deposit or residue must remain on surface to be welded after cleaning operation.
Use suction air to remove metal particles on repaired components.
Use a clean soft cloth, dampened with (PWC11-027)petroleum solvent or equivalent to remove polishing compound residue and other foreign material particles.
This task describes the procedure for cleaning components with an aqueous cleaner when it is possible to trap solvent in the component.

note.para: The aqueous cleaner is used on all parts (except bearings) to remove light oils, grease, fingerprints, dust, and soot for dimensional/visual inspection, assembly, and test.

l1item.para: Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Remove the component from the engine and place it on a clean, dry bench.

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

l1item.para: Spray or wipe the component with the (PWC11-069) aqueous cleaner, (PWC11-069A) aqueous cleaner, (PWC11-069B) aqueous cleaner, (PWC11-069C) aqueous cleaner.

note.para: If necessary, use a soft non-metallic brush or pad to help clean the part.

l1item.para: Wipe the component dry with a clean cloth.
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
If applicable, install the component on the engine.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

warning.para: CONTROL THE AIR PRESSURE TO 29 psig (200 kPa) MAXIMUM. WEAR GOGGLES OR A FACE SHIELD TO PROTECT YOUR EYES.

Use a spray or a brush to apply (PWC11-036) solvent to the electrical contacts.
Connect and disconnect the plug and socket two or three times to clean the contacts.
Use a spray or a brush to apply (PWC11-041) cleaner or (PWC11-014) isopropyl alcohol to the electrical contacts.

warning.para: CONTROL THE AIR PRESSURE TO 29 psig (200 kPa) MAXIMUM. WEAR GOGGLES OR A FACE SHIELD TO PROTECT YOUR EYES.

l1item.para: Dry the connectors with dry, filtered compressed air.
Hold the connector in a vertical position, apply a small amount of the (PWC05-256)electrical contact enhancer into the contact socket or on the contact pins as follows:

l2item.para: Use the kit supplied lint-free swab applicator and wet the contact socket surface face and if applicable, contact pins, with the (PWC05-256)electrical contact enhancer .

note.para: If the ambient temperature is too cold for the solution to flow into the sockets, the solution can be diluted. Use as much as four parts (PWC11-014)isopropyl alcohol and one part (PWC05-256) electrical contact enhancer.

l2item.para: To make sure the solution goes into the socket contacts, remove the cotton tip material from the kit-supplied applicator. Carefully insert the plastic tip into the socket to push the solution into the socket.
If the (PWC05-256)electrical contact enhancer solution was diluted, let the part air dry at room temperature for one hour minimum.

The primary purpose of repair is to enable a component or engine part to be reworked to a condition which will provide safe operation. Approved repair schemes are detailed in the relevant sections of this manual using the various consumables listed in INTRODUCTION.

A tungsten inert gas fusion welding process must be used when repairing cracks in engine parts. Argon or helium gas may be used in inert gas welding; however, argon is preferred by Pratt & Whitney Canada because its greater density reduces its rate of diffusion with the atmosphere.

Inert gas welding is a gas arc welding process which uses inert gas to protect the weld area from the surrounding atmosphere. The heat necessary for welding is provided by a very intense electric arc which is struck between a non-consumable (PWC05-147) thoriated tungsten (tungsten and thorium alloy) electrode and the metal part. On repairs where a filler material is required, a welding rod, of appropriate material, is fed into the weld area and melted with the base metal in the same manner as in conventional gas welding.
The following equipment is required for the inert gas welding process:

l2item.para: An AC/DC arc welder with high frequency controls.
A Linde HW-10 torch, or equivalent, with circulating water equipment, and ceramic cups of suitable size.

warning.para: IF AN OXYGEN REGULATOR IS USED WITH ARGON GAS, DO NOT REINSTALL REGULATOR ON AN OXYGEN CYLINDER. ARGON GAS IS NOT FREE FROM OIL AND THE POSSIBILITY EXISTS OF AN EXPLOSION CAUSED BY PRESENCE OF OIL IN THE REGULATOR.

l2item.para: An argon gas regulator.
Two flowmeters.

l1item.para: Welding must be carried out only by certified personnel.

l2item.para: Connect one argon gas flowmeter to torch and connect other flowmeter, if necessary, behind crack as a backup when ready to weld.
Connect torch to arc welder for straight polarity.

Insert a 1/16 inch diameter thoriated tungsten electrode onto torch, allowing approximately 5/16 inch of electrode to protrude from ceramic cup. The ceramic cup used must not be smaller than a No. 6 for the HW-10 torch, in order to provide a sufficient amount of inert gas to the weld area where cleanliness of the surface beader is important.

note.para: A plain tungsten electrode may be used, but a needle point must be maintained on the electrode for more positive starting of arc. Where possible, the electrode must be kept clean of material pickup.

l2item.para: If it is necessary to protect underside of weld from contamination, possible weld porosity, or poor surface finish, attach argon gas line behind crack to be welded. This may be accomplished by fabrication of small box-like fixtures having edges shaped to fit contours of part to be welded and using a suitable connection to secure gas line. Seal fixture to part in order to conserve gas leakage to minimum.

note.para: The amount of gas pressure to provide sufficient backup must be determined. This pressure should not allow the gas to stir the weld puddle. Do not use flux when welding in an inert atmosphere.

l2item.para: When high frequency controls are used, it is not necessary to strike an arc. Hold torch vertically to work so that the shielding gas (argon) forms a protective envelope around the weld. It is preferable to have area to be welded in a horizontal position.

When high frequency controls are not used, strike arc and hold electrode tip approximately 1/8 to 1/4 inch above surface to be welded until a puddle is formed. Add welding rod, as applicable, and proceed as in conventional gas welding.

note.para: Test welds, using corresponding material of same thickness and joint design, should be made to determine correct gas pressure and arc welding settings.

l2item.para: Because a high percentage of steel parts used in the engine are fabricated from 12 percent chromium corrosion-resistant steels, which are characterized by their susceptibility to air hardening, field repair of cracks by fusion welding is a special problem. The high temperature at which fusion weld repairs are made and the subsequent air cooling of the part, or parts, from these temperatures usually results in an increase in material hardness and a loss in ductility. Parts on which fusion weld repairs have been made have a tendency to crack because the steel structure becomes unstable, brittle and highly stressed. The structure of the material can be improved by reheating the parts and controlling the cooling rate.

l1item.para: Components which are not highly stressed may be repaired by fusion welding. If is possible to partially restore the original properties of such welded parts through use of local heat treatment. The localized heat may be applied by neutral flame of an oxyacetylene torch. Extend the stress relief one inch minimum beyond the welded area. After the desired heat has been applied to the part for the correct length of time, reduce temperature of part gradually.
Refer to STANDARD PRACTICES - INSPECTION.
Blend repair using carborundum stones.
Polish blended area using (PWC05-061) crocus cloth .

caution.para: DO NOT POLISH WITH POWER TOOLS.

l1item.para: Blend all repairs and finish smoothly.
Lines, scratches, or sharp edges which may cause a concentration of stress are not permitted.

caution.para: BEFORE USING HELICAL COIL INSERTS, IN ANY PART OF ENGINE, REFER TO APPLICABLE ILLUSTRATED PARTS CATALOG, APPROVED LOCATIONS AND PARTICULAR PART NUMBER OF INSERT.

Clean out hole and ensure swarf and other foreign matter is removed.

Using new helical coil insert, install insert into threaded hole using insert installation tool. Insert outer thread must be between one and one-half threads below surface of hole or counterbore, whichever applies.
Cut off driving tang at notch using approved tang removal tool and remove tang from holes.
Inspect repaired hole.

Consideration should, however, be given to reduction of thickness of walls or parent metal around insert and the required strength. This section contains information for engine on-wing ground operation. Checks and adjustment/test procedures verify the integrity of installed/replaced items. Precautions are given for safety of personnel and avoidance of engine damage and should be observed (together with appropriate precautions listed in the relevant airframe manufacturer's manual) before and during engine ground running. Detailed information given on engine test data, overtemperature, overspeed, and engine ground run Operating Limits are tabulated. Ground running is subdivided into four main checks

The operating procedures contained in this section are based on Pratt & Whitney Canada supplied items; no attempt has been made to cover airframe supplied items for the many possible variations in installation. Likewise the performance curves are based on the uninstalled engine. Thus, for up-to-date technical accuracy and performance checks, the power plant section of the applicable Airframe Maintenance Manual takes precedence and reference must be made to it.

Great care must be taken, when handling or working on turbine powered aircraft, to avoid injury to personnel and damage to property and engine. Areas of extreme danger are the air intake and exhaust jet wake.

graphic.title: Air Intake and Exhaust Jet Wake Danger Areas

l1item.para: The air intake is capable of generating sufficient suction to pull a person into the intake ducting. The potential danger of this suction cannot be over-emphasized; in an idling engine it may be sufficient to cause ingestion of eyeglasses, small tools, rags and small objects in general.

taskproc.title: Exhaust Jet Wake Area - Engine Running

l1item.para: The exhaust jet wake must be approached with extreme caution as extensive damage can be incurred from the high temperature and high velocity gases. At high engine speeds, the jet wake may propel loose dirt, sizeable stones, sand and debris over a considerable distance. The high temperatures in the wake are sufficient to deteriorate asphalt, and for this reason concrete is recommended for run-up areas.

Occasionally, when starting a jet engine, an accumulation of fuel in the exhaust tail pipe is blown out as long streams of flame. Personnel should observe proper fire precautions and move all flammable material to a safe distance.

Exposure to gases in the jet wake should be avoided. Failure to do so may result in respiratory irritations and a burning sensation in the eyes. Particular care should be taken to avoid exposure to gases in confined spaces where the gas concentration may be high.

After engine operation, work that requires contact with the exhaust tailpipe should not be carried out for at least one-half hour. Heat resistant gloves must be worn, should work in this area be required immediately after shutdown.
All jet fuels and lubricating oils have an injurious effect on the skin. Precautions must be taken to avoid contact as much as possible.

taskproc.title: Precipitation
taskproc.para: Performance checks should not be attempted during moderate to heavy precipitation or fog. Water entering the engine inlet changes the power output of the engine, the change being proportional to the amount of water ingested. Any form of moisture in the air causes the engine to ingest water. This includes occasions when water or snow is blown into the air inlet, or sucked in by the compressor. Freezing rain or slush snow has exactly the same effect on power output as water ingestion and, in addition, may cling to inlet ducts and upset the flow of air to the engine.

caution.para: CAREFULLY MONITOR FUEL AND OIL PRESSURES DURING STARTING OF AN ENGINE WHICH HAS BEEN EXPOSED TO OVERNIGHT LOW AMBIENT TEMPERATURE. SHUT DOWN ENGINE IMMEDIATELY IF, IN EITHER SYSTEM, THERE IS NO INDICATION OR AN INDICATION WHICH IS OUTSIDE OF NORMAL OPERATING LIMITS. INSPECT FOR ICE IN BOTH SYSTEMS. IF PRESENT, APPLY HOT AIR TO THE INLET AREA USING SUITABLE HEATING EQUIPMENT BEFORE ATTEMPTING ANOTHER START.

l1item.para: Solubility of water in fuel diminishes with reducing temperatures resulting in water fuel separation, with the water tending to accumulate at the lowest level of tank, system of affected component. Further temperature reduction or continued cold soaking of the engine causes formation of ice particles which may partially block the fuel system filters, thus reducing fuel flow. In extreme conditions total blockage of the strainer(s) may occur, indicated by a marked reduction or complete loss of fuel flow to the engine. The application of heat to engine and fuel system components will prevent or remedy such instances.

Similar conditions of ice formation can exist in the engine lubrication system due to condensation in the tank or engine case area. Shutting down a hot engine in low ambient temperature conditions, followed by a cold soak in the open, will certainly increase the probability of ice formation in both fuel and lubrication systems.
No special precautions or procedures are required for engine starting during hot weather.

note.para: The following procedure is used to clear the engine at any time during ground operation if it is necessary to purge the engine of internally trapped fuel and vapors, such as prior to checking for igniter function. Air passing through the engine will remove fuel or vapor from the combustion section area, turbines and engine exhaust nozzle.

l1item.para: Electrical Power - ON
Thrust Lever Angle - IDLE.
Ignition Switch - OFF.
Fuel Pump - AUTO or ON (To provide lubrication for engine driven fuel pumping elements).
Engine Starter Switch - START then RUN.
The FADEC will automatically stop the dry motoring cycle after 30 seconds. Observe starter limits (Refer to the Aircraft Flight Manual).
Engine Starter Switch - STOP.
Electrical Power - OFF.
Allow required cooling period for the starter before any further starting operation is attempted (Refer to the Aircraft Flight Manual).

caution.para: THE FADEC WILL DETECT AN IGNITION OUTPUT FAULT (NO DISPATCHABLE FAULT) IF THE IGNITION CIRCUIT BREAKERS HAVE BEEN PULLED.

numlitem.para: A Wet Motoring Run is used to prime the engine fuel system.
A Wet Motoring Run should be followed by two Dry Motoring Runs.
It is recommended that a Wet Motoring Run be done before starting the engine if maintenance work has been done on the engine fuel system since the previous start, followed by two Dry Motoring Runs.

Thrust Lever Angle - IDLE.
Engine Starter Switch - STOP.
Open ignition circuit breakers.
Ignition Switch - AUTO.
Fuel Pump - AUTO or ON.
Engine Starter Switch - START then RUN.
Monitor N2, fuel flow, fuel pressure and oil pressure during wet motoring.

Since the EEC cannot distinguish between a wet motoring cycle and a normal start, an abort start indication will occur if the wet motoring cycle lasts more than 15 seconds. This is normal operation. Observe the starter limits (Refer to the Aircraft Flight Manual).
Engine Starter Switch - STOP.
Electrical Power - OFF.
Allow the required cooling period for the starter before any further starting operation is attempted (Refer to the Aircraft Flight Manual).
Do two Dry Motoring Runs.

Do the Prestart Checks (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-809).

Engine Starter Switch - STOP to START then RUN.
Monitor ITT and observe that the engine accelerates normally to Ground Idle (54% N2).
Engine Oil Pressure Indicator - check normal operating limits (Ref. Task 05-10-00-990-801).

caution.para: THE ENGINE MUST ACHIEVE STABILIZED GROUND IDLE WITHIN 45 SECONDS OF "FUEL ON" (8% N2) OR THE FADEC WILL CAUSE AN AUTOMATIC START ABORT ON THE GROUND. THE HP ROTOR SHOULD BE ALLOWED TO STOP BEFORE ATTEMPTING ANOTHER START. OBSERVE THE STARTER LIMITS (REFER TO THE AIRCRAFT FLIGHT MANUAL).
IF N2 REACHES 40% OR HIGHER WITH NO INDICATION OF N1 ROTATION, ABORT THE START.

task.title: Check No. 4 - Engine Calibration (Five Point Calibration)

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for doing an engine calibration ground run.

Upon initial installation of a new, spare or overhauled engine, a ground calibration run (Task 71-00-00-760-812) must be done to establish the relationships between N1, N2 and ITT on the installed engine.
A ground calibration run must be completed and compared to the reference charts after hot section inspection (HSI), LP compressor rotor (fan) replacement or fan repair.
The curves obtained from the calibration run shall be regarded as reference charts which must be used to assess the engine's performance at subsequent ground checks.

note.para: It is necessary to do an accurate calibration check to make sure that future engine ground checks provide meaningful data.

l1item.para: Data on engine operating performance is to be read from the aircraft cockpit instruments.

caution.para: DO NOT PERFORM THE ENGINE CALIBRATION RUN IN HIGH WIND OR MODERATE TO HEAVY RAIN, SNOW OR FOG CONDITIONS.

note.para: Engine performance is greatly affected by local atmospheric conditions.

l1item.para: Prepare to do an engine ground calibration run for new, spare or overhauled engines to obtain calibration curves as follows:

l2item.para: Make a copy of the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet to use during the calibration ground run (Ref. Fig. ).
Make a copy of each of the two Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curve Charts to use during the calibration ground run (Ref. Fig. and Fig.).
Make sure the instrumentation is functioning correctly and has been accurately calibrated per the applicable AMM, if necessary.

Obtain the trim data values for N1 (%) and ITT (°C) stamped on the engine trim data plate found on the AGB (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-802) and record them on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig.).
Position the aircraft into the wind and away from the influence of buildings or other obstacles and ensure the wind speed is less than 25 knots with N1 fluctuation remaining below ±0.5%.
Obtain the local ambient air temperature (tamb) in °C from the airport tower.
Obtain the local pressure altitude in feet from the aircraft cockpit instruments or the airport tower.
Record the local tamb and pressure altitude values on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig.).

Refer to Fig., Power Assurance Test Chart - N1 vs Ambient Temperature, to obtain the target N1% at TO (with ECS bleeds off) power for the OAT and pressure altitude recorded. Record the target N1 value on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig. Fig.).

Check for engine fault / maintenance messages or indications on the aircraft maintenance display (Refer to the AMM). Record fault codes on a copy of EEC Fault Code Data Sheet, Fig.). To review the Fault Codes, refer to Task 72-00-02-810-801.
Make sure all accessory loads are OFF.
Make sure Cabin Bleed and Anti-icing Bleeds are selected OFF.

N2

l1item.para: Re-adjust the throttle, and record the six operating parameter values listed above on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet at each of the six following power settings:

numlitem.para: Allow the engine to stabilize for a minimum of three minutes at the Normal Takeoff power setting. Check that the engine N1 value is within ±0.5% of the previously recorded target N1 value. Allow the engine to stabilize for a minimum of three minutes for each remaining power setting.
When moving to the required power setting, move the thrust lever in one direction only. Reduced scatter is preferable for even spacing of calibration points on the plot.
The first Normal Take-off point is to make sure that the target is correct.
The data points can be taken in either direction, however it is recommended to perform the points from low to high power to allow the engine to stabilize.

l2item.para: Normal Take-off (TO)

note.para: Normal Take-off is TO/GA.

l2item.para: Ground Idle
Normal TO-8%
Normal TO-6%
Normal TO-4%,
Normal TO-2%
Normal TO

l1item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure after the ground calibration run has been completed (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
Convert observed N1, N2 and ITT data to corrected data as follows (Ref. Table):

note.para: The values in Table are conversion factors created for convenient computation of corrected ITT.

ITT (°C) corrected =
ITT observed

l2item.para: Example:
Sample calculation:

l1item.para: Record the corrected N1, N2 and ITT values on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig.).
Plot the corrected data as follows using the values recorded on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig.):

l2item.para: Refer to the copies of the Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curve charts (Ref. Fig. and Fig.).
Plot the corrected N1 vs corrected N2 values on the MAXIMUM CORRECTED N2 CHART, (Ref. Fig.).
Plot the corrected N1 vs corrected ITT values on the MAXIMUM CORRECTED ITT chart (Ref.Fig.).

note.para: If it is not possible to plot the final N1 conditions on the plot axes provided due to high or low ambient temperatures, use the remaining usable conditions only.

l1item.para: If excessive scatter is apparent after the data has been plotted, check conversion calculations. If no errors, repeat the ground run at the applicable engine power setting(s).

Performance points plotted on Figure and Figure are for comparison purposes with data from the same engine taken at different flight hour times. Review of the data over a period of time can allow determination of deterioration or unresolved issues with the installation. Contact the P&WC Customer Support Help Desk for further assistance (Ref. INTRODUCTION).

table.title: Ambient Temperature Correction Factors for Specified Temperatures

l1item.para: Keep the completed Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet and the plotted Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curves with the engine logbook for future reference.
Do the Power Assurance Check, if required (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813).
This task gives the procedure for doing the engine Power Assurance Check.

A performance check is to be done after completion of work on gas path components as required by Major Component Repair/Replacement (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-804), or the engine performance deterioration fault isolation procedure. Record the required, observed and calculated parameters on the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, (Ref. Fig.).

note.para: The power assurance test will determine if an engine will develop take-off power within N2 and ITT limits up to the maximum Tamb and altitude for which the engine is certified. Operators should use this information to schedule engine maintenance activity.
To make sure the engine can supply the necessary power, margins must not have negative values.

caution.para: DO NOT PERFORM THE POWER ASSURANCE TEST IN HIGH WIND OR MODERATE TO HEAVY RAIN, SNOW OR FOG CONDITIONS.

note.para: Engine performance is greatly affected by local atmospheric conditions.

l1item.para: Make a copy of the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure to use during the ground run.
Make sure the instrumentation is functioning correctly and has been accurately calibrated per the applicable AMM.
Position the aircraft into the wind and away from the influence of buildings or other obstacles and ensure the wind speed is less than 25 knots with N1 fluctuation remaining below ±0.5%.
Do the engine prestart procedure (Task 71-00-00-760-809).
Obtain the local ambient temperature (Tamb) in °C from the airport tower.
Obtain the local pressure altitude in feet from the aircraft cockpit instruments (Refer to the AMM) or from the airport tower.
Record the local tamb and pressure altitude values on the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure.
Record the ITT trim and N1 trim values stamped on the engine trim data plate (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-802) onto the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure.

Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-812 Check No. 4 - Engine Calibration (Five Point Calibration) Figure, Power Assurance Test Chart - N1 vs Ambient Temperature to obtain the target N1% at TO power with all bleeds off for the tamb and pressure altitude recorded during the Power Assurance Check. Record the target N1 value on the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure.
Do the engine start procedure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).

note.para: Do not open any of the bleeds.

l1item.para: Check for EEC fault indications (Refer to the AMM). Record fault codes on a copy of EEC Fault Code Data Sheet, Figure). To review the EEC Fault Codes (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801).
Make sure all accessory loads are OFF.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED MAXIMUM VALUES OF N2 AND ITT. IF EITHER MAXIMUM VALUE IS EXCEEDED, (REF. Task 72-00-01-810-801) FOR CORRECTIVE ACTION. FOLLOWING RECTIFICATION, REPEAT THE POWER ASSURANCE CHECK.

l1item.para: Advance the thrust lever to the TO detent. Allow the engine rpm to stabilize for a recommended minimum of three minutes. Check that the engine N1 value is within ±0.5% of previously recorded target N1 value.
Record the following operating parameter values:

numlitem.para: N1
N2
ITT
Tamb
PA

note.para: The Tamb and Pamb values recorded during the Job Setup may have changed.

l2item.para: Plot the recorded ITT value on the Power Assurance Test Chart - ITT vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig.) at the recorded Tamb and PA values.
Plot the recorded N2 value on the Power Assurance Test Chart - N2 vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig. ) at the recorded Tamb and PA values.
Check and record the ITT and N2 margins, i.e. the difference between the maximum N2 and ITT for the values at the recorded Tamb, PA , N2 and ITT values.

note.para: Interpolation might be required to determine maximum N2 and ITT if the airport altitude is between the lines on the power assurance charts.

l1item.para: If desired, do the engine shutdown procedure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
If the recorded N2 and/or ITT values are close to or at the limits Engine Performance Deterioration (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-801).

graphic.title: Power Assurance Test Chart - N2 vs Ambient Temperature
Power Assurance Test Chart - ITT vs Ambient Temperature

l1item.para: Determine target N1:

l2item.para: Enter Power Assurance Test Chart - N1 vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig. ) at Tamb of 21°C, and PA of 500 ft.
Target N1 is 91.8%.

l1item.para: Sample engine recorded parameters at T/O power with all bleeds OFF:

l2item.para: At Tamb 21°C and PA 500 ft.
N1 is 91.5% which is within 0.5% of target N1 (91.8%).
Recorded ITT is 775°C.
Recorded N2 is 98.2%.

l1item.para: Calculate the difference (Δ) between maximum N2 and ITT, and recorded N2 and ITT:

l2item.para: Enter Power Assurance Test Chart - N2 vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig.) at Tamb 21°C and PA 500 ft.
Max. N2 is 99.2%.
The difference (ΔN2) is maximum N2 minus recorded N2 99.2% - 98.2% = 1%

note.para: The 1% value is the available N2 margin to the engine limit.

l2item.para: Enter Power Assurance Test Chart - ITT vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig.) at Tamb 21°C and PA 500 ft.
Max. ITT is 787°C.
The difference (ΔITT) = (maximum ITT) - (recorded ITT) 787°C - 775°C = 12°C.

note.para: The 12°C value is the available ITT margin to the engine limit.

l1item.para: Keep the completed Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet and the plotted Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curves with the engine logbook for future reference.
This task gives the procedure for checking the engine main oil pressure (MOP).
Not applicable.
Do the prestart checks (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-809).
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).
Position the aircraft into the wind.
Operate the engine at GROUND IDLE speed for two minutes minimum and allow engine oil temperature to stabilize.
Advance the power lever to achieve target TAKEOFF power. Record MOP and MOT when stabilized. Do not exceed three minutes at TAKEOFF power.
Move the power lever to achieve GROUND IDLE speed and allow the engine to stabilize for two minutes.
Shut the engine down (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
The recorded MOP value must be within the limits shown on Figure :

l2item.para: If recorded MOP is within Figure limits, no further action is required.
If recorded MOP is not within Figure limits, the cold start valve can be adjusted per engine main oil pressure (MOP) adjustment (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-815.

graphic.title: Engine Main Oil Pressure Setting Graph

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for adjusting the engine main oil pressure.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

caution.para: DO NOT ADJUST OIL PRESSURE TO COMPENSATE FOR UNRESOLVED OIL SYSTEM PROBLEMS (REF. Task 72-00-01-810-801). THIS COULD CAUSE MOP TO BE OUT OF SPECIFIED LIMITS AND CAUSE DAMAGE TO OIL SYSTEM COMPONENTS.

l1item.para: Loosen the two bolts (1) so that the flange (3) can be lifted off the cover (4).

note.para: It is not necessary to remove the flange (3) to do the MOP adjustment.

l1item.para: Turn the hexagonal nut on the cover (4) clockwise CW to increase the engine oil pressure or counter-clockwise CCW to decrease the engine oil pressure.

note.para: The cover (4) has 24 tangs (2), partially visible through the slots in the flange (3). A rotation of one tang changes the engine oil pressure by approximately 3.6 psi.

l1item.para: If a new cold start valve was installed, make sure that the nominal setting procedure was done (Ref. Task 79-20-05-400-801.
Engage the slots in the flange (3) with the tangs (2) of the cover (4) at the desired MOP setting.
Torque the two bolts (1) to 36 to 40 lb.in. to secure the flange to the oil pump.
Do the Engine MOP Check to confirm that MOP is within the limits shown on Figure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-814).

task.title: Engine N1 and ITT Trim Adjustment

l1item.para: This task is used to adjust engine N1 and ITT trims, utilization information and engine serial number.

caution.para: REPLACING BOTH THE EEC AND THE DCU AT THE SAME TIME FOR ANY REASON, WILL REQUIRE A SPECIAL INITIALIZATION PROCEDURE TO BE PERFORMED. PRIOR TO PERFORMING THIS TASK, CONTACT P&WC TO PERFORM THE PROCEDURE.

REPLACING THE EEC OR THE DCU WILL RESULT IN AN AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION OF ENGINE TRIMS. EXCHANGING A DCU FROM ONE ENGINE TO ANOTHER WILL CAUSE THE INCORRECT TRIMS TO BE LOADED ON THE ENGINE. IF THIS OCCURS, INITIALIZE AS DESCRIBED IN THIS TASK.

l1item.para: This procedure may be used:

l2item.para: If the DCU is replaced with a new DCU.
After a shop visit (new, unscheduled or overhaul) to update the usage information.
When the engine is installed on the aircraft.

numlitem.para: When an EEC is replaced, the EEC will automatically update its own trims and operational data from the DCU.
When the DCU is replaced with a new unit, the EEC will automatically initialize the DCU.

l1item.para: If replacing both the EEC and the DCU at the same time, a special procedure is required prior to performing this procedure. Contact P&WC to perform the procedure.
There are two methods available to complete this procedure:

l2item.para: Method 1, using a (PWC40549) DCU Cable with External Power. This method may be used when the DCU is on a bench, or the if the engine is on a build stand. The power supply for the DCU is built into the ( PWC40549)DCU Cable with External Power .

Method 2, using (3074497) DPHM Kit . This method may be used when the DCU is installed on an engine, and the engine is installed on an aircraft. The power supply for the DCU comes from the aircraft via the FADEC and engine harness when using the (3074497) DPHM Kit .

l1item.para: Install a new DCU. Refer to Task 77-40-01-400-801.
Make sure the aircraft system and engine EEC are powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Make sure the aircraft has ON GROUND status.
Make sure the engine has been shut down and is not operating.

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT BOTH ENGINES HAVE BEEN SHUT DOWN AND ARE NOT OPERATING.

l1item.para: METHOD 1 (Using (PWC40549) cable:

l2item.para: Remove the DCU from the engine. Refer to Task 77-40-01-000-801.
Connect (PWC40549)cable to the DCU, to a commercial AC wall outlet and to a laptop.
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181), from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select TRIM/UPLOAD.
Enter the data from the source indicated, into the column marked New Val as shown in Tables and .
After the values are entered, click the WRITE button to send the data to the DCU. Confirm that the Current Val. column now shows the correct data.
Disconnect (PWC40549)cable from the DCU, the commercial AC wall outlet and from the laptop.
Install the DCU on the engine. Refer to Task 77-40-01-400-801.
Do an Engine Trim Verification Check. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-817.

l1item.para: METHOD 2 (Using (3074497) DPHM Kit :

l2item.para: Loosen and remove the engine wiring harness P36 connector from the DCU using the (PWC90012)pliers.
Connect the (3074497)DPHM Kit cable to the DCU, to engine wiring harness P36 connector and to a laptop computer per instructions provided with the kit.
Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181), from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select TRIM/UPLOAD.
Enter the data from the source indicated, into the column marked New Val as shown in Tables and .
After the values are entered, click the WRITE button to send the data to the DCU. Confirm that the Current Val. column now shows the correct data.
De-energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Disconnect the (3074497)DPHM Kit cable from the DCU, from the engine wiring harness P36 connector and from the laptop computer.
Connect the engine wiring harness P36 connector to the DCU electrical connector. Refer to Task 73-20-02-400-801 or to Task 73-20-02-400-803.
Do an Engine Trim Verification Check. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-817.

entry.para: NOTE: The engine serial number should be entered using CAPITAL LETTERS. If capital letters are not entered, the engine will not issue a fault, but the aircraft data system will not correctly save the engine data to it's flash card system.

note.para: The FADEC calculates these values automatically. If these records disagree with the Engine Logbook, the Logbook shall take precedence.

l1item.para: This task is to verify the N1 and ITT engine trims after engine replacement, EEC replacement and/or DCU replacement.
There are two methods available:

l2item.para: Verify trims using the engine maintenance page on the aircraft primary flight display, (Refer to the AMM). No tools are required.
Verify trims using PWC ground based software (Ref. Introduction).

l1item.para: Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: METHOD 1: Do the Engine Trim Verification using the aircraft avionics. Refer to the AMM for procedure.

note.para: Engine trims are available on the Aircraft Avionics ENGINE MAINTENANCE PAGE.

l1item.para: METHOD 2: Do the Engine Trim Verification using the Ground Based Software (part of DPHM Kit P/N 3074497).
This task describes how to download the engine DCU data which can be used for remote analysis by maintenance personnel, advanced diagnostics or to download ECTM data as a backup to the primary.
To download the engine DCU data, get access to the engine compartment and connection directly to the DCU.
If the DCU is unserviceable and cannot be interrogated, then the EEC may be interrogated (Ref Task 71-00-00-760-819).
Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostic, and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

note.para: Do this task if setting up the Ground Based Software (GBSLite) for the first time or if setting up on a new laptop computer.
It is recommended, but not mandatory, to have a dedicated laptop for the engine maintenance.

l1item.para: Administration rights are required for the installation.
For Post-SB66034R1, DPHM 2.0.4 (GBSLite version 4.02) or higher is required.
Install DPHM Suite, as follows:

l2item.para: Put the CD in the laptop. If the DPHM Suite Installer screen opens, continue to step (d). If the screen does not automatically open to install the software, continue to step (b).
Double-click on the CD drive in My Computer. If the DPHM Suite Installer screen opens, continue to step (d). If the screen does not automatically open to install the software, continue to step (c).
Double-click on DPHMInstaller.exe from the CD contents. Continue to step (d).
Make sure that the components that are required to be installed are selected.
Select the “Install” button.
Follow the on-screen instructions.

l1item.para: If the DPHM kit includes (PWC73009) adapter, install the drivers. Refer to the GBSLite help manual. The help manual is available by opening GBSLite and selecting the “Help” button. The instructions for installation are in section “USB-Serial Port Adapter Setup Instructions”.

note.para: The USB connector must always be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l1item.para: It is recommended, but not mandatory, that the computer’s anti-virus and wireless network adapter be disabled when using GBS software.

taskproc.title: Engine DCU Download via Aircraft GSE Connector (Pre-SB66034 Only)

l1item.para: Connect download (PWC69810) cable adapter to the maintenance connector.
Connect (PWC62174)extension cable to download (PWC69810) cable adapter.

Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to (PWC62174)extension cable. Connect the (PWC73009)connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN A" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled “RS422 TO USB CHAN B" disconnected.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to USB end of the cable to laptop.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed. The USB connector must be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l1item.para: Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617F.
Perform Engine Real Time Display task (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-820) and confirm LOOP is equal to 26.

If LOOP is not equal to 26, return to the GBSLite menu, connect the connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN B" into the Uport 1250 and disconnect the connector labeled “RS422 TO USB CHAN A". Perform Engine Real Time Display task (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-820) and confirm LOOP is equal to 26.
Under the option of GSE CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD.

note.para: The help symbol “?” within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l1item.para: Click “OK” to establish communication.
To trigger the download process; move TLA to the TO/GA and switch cockpit ignition switch from AUTO to OFF for more than 2 seconds.
If the download does not work, perform the Verify GSE Download Conditions in the Engine Real Time Display task (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-820).

note.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l1item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Make sure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: METHOD 1: Connection directly to the Engine DCU using ( PWC40549)Cable with External Power .

l2item.para: Remove the DCU from the engine.
Connect (PWC40549)cable to the DCU, to a commercial AC wall outlet and to a laptop via a serial port.
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD DCU.

numlitem.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l2item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: METHOD 2: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with Aircraft Power DPHM Kit P/N 3074497 (Ref Fig. 513).

l2item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DPHM Kit P/N 3074497 Ref. (Fig. :

l3item.para: Connect DCU (PWC40712)adapter cable to the DCU.
Connect P36 to DCU (PWC40712) adapter cable.
Connect DCU (PWC40712)adapter cable to (PWC62174) extension cable.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter (PWC62174) extension cable.
Connect the USB end of the RS422-USB (PWC73009)dual channel adapter to a laptop.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed. The USB connector must be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l2item.para: Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Start GBSLite from the main menu.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD DCU.

numlitem.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l2item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: METHOD 3: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with DCU (PWC67792)T-harness Cable .

l2item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DCU T-Harness Cable, connect (PWC67792) cable to the DCU at P36 and to a laptop via the serial port.
Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Start GBSLite from the main menu.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD DCU.

numlitem.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes.

l2item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: This task describes how to download the engine DCU data which can be used for remote analysis by maintenance personnel, advanced diagnostics or to download ECTM data as a backup to the primary.
This task should only be used if the engine DCU data is not accessible because of an unserviceable DCU.
To obtain the complete EEC Data Download, it is necessary to download both EEC channel A and EEC channel B per engine.
Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: Make sure that the Ground Based Software (GBS) and RS422 adapter USB drivers are installed as per section D of Task 71-00-00-760-818.
Connect (PWC69810)download cable adapter to the maintenance connector.
Connect (PWC62174)extension cable to download cable adapter.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to extension cable.
For EEC channel A download, connect the (PWC73009)dual channel adapter labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN A" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled “RS422 TO USB CHAN B" disconnected.
For EEC channel B download, connect the connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN B" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled “RS422 TO USB CHAN A" disconnected.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to laptop and connect the other end to the aircraft ground support equipment connector within the aircraft (Ref. Fig. 513) Refer to the AMM.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed. The USB connector must be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l1item.para: Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Under the option of GSE CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD.

note.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
If the ignition switch is already OFF, set it back to AUTO, and then start the procedure.

l1item.para: Move the TLA to the MAX detent and set the cockpit ignition switch from AUTO to OFF. Make sure the switch remains in the OFF position.

note.para: It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l1item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: Cycle EEC power and repeat for the other channel.
Once both channels are downloaded, contact P&WC personnel to indicate that a DCU download was not possible.

numlitem.para: If the download does not work, do the Verify GSE Download Conditions in the Engine Real Time Display (Task 71-00-00-760-820).
TLA positions are as follows:

l1item.para: This task describes how to view both channels of EEC real-time data, at the same time, on the same engine.
This task may be used for the following reasons:

unlitem.para: To diagnose problems with the engine control system.
To check/verify engine EEC data vs. aircraft data.
To record information to be used for advanced remote analysis.

l1item.para: Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: Ensure that the Ground Based Software (GBS) and RS422 adapter USB drivers are installed as per section D of task 71-00-00-760-818.
Connect download (PWC69810) cable adapter to the maintenance connector.
Connect (PWC62174)extension cable to download (PWC69810) cable adapter.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to (PWC62174)extension cable.
For EEC channel A download, connect the (PWC73009)dual channel adapter labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN A" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled “RS422 TO USB CHAN B" disconnected.
For EEC channel B download, connect the connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN B" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled “RS422 TO USB CHAN A" disconnected.

Connect the USB end of the RS422-USB (PWC73009)dual channel adapter to the laptop and connect the other end to the aircraft ground support equipment connector in the aircraft. (Ref. Fig. 513) (Refer to the AMM).
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Under the option of GSE CONNECTION, select REAL TIME DISPLAY.

note.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.

l1item.para: Follow the on-screen menu to view parameters as supplied by the engine EEC.

To perform the Verify GSE Download Conditions function, select CLICK TO START VERIFY and follow the on-screen instructions. To end the Verify GSE Download Conditions function, select CLICK TO STOP VERIFY.
To perform a Real-Time Display recording, select the START RECORDING button. To end the recording, select the STOP RECORDING button. Follow the on-screen instructions.
This task describes how to review and analyze data that was previously downloaded from the engine or data from a recorded Real Time Display (RTD).
This task may be used to analyze/diagnose unscheduled maintenance events. It is intended for use by P&WC personnel or other experienced personnel.
There are four sources of data that may be used for data analysis:

unlitem.para: Engine data from the engine DCU.
Engine data from the engine EEC.
Engine data from the aircraft Avionics Flash Card.
Engine data from the aircraft Data Link Management System.

l1item.para: Not applicable.

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

taskproc.title: Engine Data Analysis from DCU and/or EEC

l1item.para: Start GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the main menu.
Select the engine program from the drop down menu (PW617F).
Select "Data Analysis".
Select the folder where the data is.
Proceed with analysis of the data.

To view the trend data, select “Fault Event/Show Trend Data” from “View” dropdown menu. If the trend data from the latest flights are not available in GBSLite, perform the DCU Pointer Block Recovery function Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-826 in GBS software.
In the Fault/Event panel (top panel), the data is sorted by data and time, the latest recording can be found at the bottom.
Click on Fault/Event Code; the name of the event code will appear at the top in red.
If the IETM, P/N 3072162 is installed, clicking on the Fault/Event Code will link to the appropriate maintenance action in fault isolation charts.
Click on the associated Snapshot and Trace for further analysis of the Fault/Event, which can be viewed in the lower panel.
The file can be sent to the Designated Analysis Center (DAC) for data analysis or can be uploaded to the WebECTM Services.
This task gives the TLD clearing procedure.
This task should be done at the scheduled TLD inspection interval (Ref. Task 05-20-00-210-801), after all the faults have been rectified.

note.para: The EEC is designed to latch a "ENG 1 LONG DISPATCH", or "ENG 2 LONG DISPATCH" TLD status, if at any time during operation, a TLD fault occurs. The status is displayed on the "Engine Maintenance Page" on the aircraft avionics. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: Aircraft system and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Aircraft must be "On ground" status.
Get access to the Aircraft Maintenance Computer. Refer to the AMM.
Move the TLA to the TOGA detent.
Activate the exceedance/TLD clearance function on the Engine Maintenance Page, for the appropriate engine. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: "CLEAR E1" for engine No. 1, and "CLEAR E2" for engine No. 2.

l1item.para: Check the engine maintenance page and make sure that LONG DISPATCH status is not active. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: The EEC must receive the command for at least two seconds to register the clear command. Therefore, it may take up to four seconds to display the updated LONG DISPATCH status on the engine maintenance page.

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for doing on-aircraft engine vibration survey and fan trim balancing. Refer to Figure.

Resonant vibration is the major contributor to aircraft cabin noise. Engine vibration causes resonant vibration in aircraft structures, exciting resonance and noise in the cabin. The maintenance philosophy for providing the following procedures is to aid in the reduction of aircraft cabin noise through the reduction of engine vibration.

Using the recommended vibration analysis equipment, engine vibration levels are measured while the engine is installed during a series of engine ground runs. Engine vibration is measured and potentially reduced by adjusting the trim balance weight configuration on the LP compressor (fan) front balance rim. A typical operation includes an initial ground run where a vibration survey is performed and a trim weight solution determined; a second ground run to measure the new vibration signature; and one or more engine runs to verify that engine vibration levels are optimized.

If excessive or undesirable cabin noise is present in the aircraft, it is recommended that cabin acoustic readings be taken using microphones according to an approved method, before performing on-wing engine vibration survey and trim balance. The cabin acoustic survey will help determine the source of the excessive noise. If it is suspected that the engine is the cause of excessive vibration and subsequent excessive cabin noise, only the fan may be trim-balanced while the engine is on the aircraft.

Current engine balancing procedures, carried out during engine test, include a requirement to trim balance the complete LP compressor assembly by the installation of counterweights to specific positions in the inlet cone assembly.

The operator must be familiar with the TEC Viper Model Collector/Analyzer before performing these operations. Do a vibration survey and fan trim balance operation using the following procedures and the TEC 'Viper' Model Operator's Manual.
P&WC recommends an engine fan trim balancing operation following repair of the fan.

Required equipment, including an optional laptop computer running TEC Avtrend software and connecting cables listed in Equipment and Materials list for this task has been approved for use in determining position and mass of trim balance counterweight. Other equipment may be approved on a case-by-case basis.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Disconnect the aircraft wiring harness connector from the engine main wiring harness connector at the aircraft firewall. Refer to the AMM.
Check the ACES analyzer battery charge:

l2item.para: Switch electrical power to the 10-100-4040CETEC Viper collector/analyzer to ON and check the battery's charge. If the battery charge indication is less than 60%, charge the battery before doing any procedures.
Switch electrical power to the 10-100-4040CETEC Viper collector/analyzer to OFF.

l1item.para: Install the latest version of the maintenance level Transient Vibration Survey/Fan Balance Setup File in the 10-100-4040CE ACES Viper collector/analyzer. The setup files may be downloaded from ACES Systems website: www.acessystems.com.
Switch electrical power to the analyzer to OFF.
Refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog, 72-30-01, for trim balance counterweight information.

note.para: The equipment below is part of (PWC68604) High Speed Trim Balancing Kit.

entry.para: Cable, Breakout Extension N1 and N2
