Installation of Collector/Analyzer Equipment - Fan Trim Balancing

entry.para: Trim Balance Counterweights - Inlet Cone Hole Numbers
Trim Balance Counterweights - Engine Data Plate Hole Numbers

l1item.para: If the fan was repaired:

l2item.para: Remove the inlet cone (Ref. Task 72-30-01-000-801).
Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-802 for engine data plate descriptions. Check the engine trim data plate and record the locations of any LP compressor trim balance counterweights on a copy of Table.

note.para: Trim balance counterweight hole locations are numbered clockwise (CW) on the rear face of the inlet cone balancing rim (Ref. Fig.).

l2item.para: Record the location of any existing counterweights on the inlet cone balance rim on a copy of Table.

note.para: A maximum of nine counterweight screws are permitted on the inlet cone balance rim.

l2item.para: Remove all existing counterweights from the inlet cone balance rim.
Install the inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-400-805.

l1item.para: Install TEC Viper Model Analyzer equipment (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Remove the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3), the angle bracket (2) and engine front lifting bracket (1).
Install the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7), the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3) and the angle bracket (2). Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).

note.para: The bracket plate should face forward.

l2item.para: Install the 69-100-0016accelerometer (5) on the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7) with the three cap screws (6). Torque the cap screws 13 to 15 lb.in. (1.5-1.7 Nm.).

caution.para: MAKE SURE YOU ATTACH THE CABLES AND THE CHARGE CONVERTER BOX SECURELY TO PREVENT LOOSENING DURING THE GROUND RUN.

l2item.para: Connect the 10-320-0008high temperature cable to the 69-100-0016accelerometer and to the 10-100-0574 charge converter box.
Connect the 10-100-0574charge converter box to the 10-100-4040CETEC Viper collector/analyzer Channel A port with 10-320-0158sensor cable (25 ft) or 10-320-0159sensor cable (50 ft).
Disconnect the engine wiring harness P9 connector from the aircraft fire wall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the aircraft harness firewall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the engine rear main wiring harness P9 connector.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the 10-100-0498dual channel tach filter with the 10-320-0336N1/N2 breakout extension cable .

l1item.para: Switch electrical power to the ViperCollector/Analyzer ON.

note.para: With the ViperCollector/Analyzer powered on, make sure the Fan/Turbine Balance application is installed.
With the ViperCollector/Analyzer powered on, make sure the battery charge battery charge indication is more than 60%. If not, charge the battery before doing any procedures.

l1item.para: At the "Main" menu, select Fan/Turbine Balance using the upper/lower curser keys then press ENTER.
Select "Start Job" using the upper/lower curser keys and press ENTER.
At the "Set-up List", select PW617F using the upper/lower curser keys then press ENTER.

note.para: Analyzer will display "Loading...Please wait.", then, "Initializing for data acquisition, please wait".

l1item.para: At the "Job identification" menu, type in the name of the customer and the aircraft serial number (e.g. John Smith Aviation ZZ-XXX) using the keypad.

note.para: The "F1" key can be used to select Names which have been already entered in the analyzer.

l1item.para: In the "A/C Registration" field, enter the aircraft registration number using the keypad.
Input the A/C Total Time using the keypad keys and press ENTER.
At the "Engine Information" menu, enter the engine position using the left and right arrow keys, then use the upper/lower curser keys to move to "ENGINE".
Press the UP and DOWN arrow keys to move the cursor to the next field. Enter additional/optional information.
Press the ENTER key to move to the next menu.
At the "Fan/Turbine Balance Speeds" menu, press the F1 survey key.

note.para: The screen will display [Prime ]Initializing for Data Aquisition....Please Wait".

l1item.para: At the "Start Aircraft" menu, the Collector/Analyzer (Viper) screen will display "Survey for determining baln RPMs perform FOD check, start engine(s) per flight manual, and set engine(s) to idle".
Start the engine. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-810.
Let the engine stabilize and oil temperature reach 125°F (51°C) minimum. Press ENTER.

note.para: If required, run the engine at a higher idle speed to warm the engine oil, then return the power lever to idle.

l1item.para: Press ENTER to start acquiring data, then gradually increase engine speed to maximum N1 rpm. When this is done, press enter to stop acquisition.
Return the engine to ground idle N1 speed. There is no need to shut the engine down.
At the “Shut down engines” field, press F5 to continue.
At the “Fan/turbine balance speeds” screen, press enter to accept the peak N1 speed recorded during the survey and proceed to next screen.

note.para: The Analyzer will display "Initializing for data aquisition, please wait.".

l1item.para: The Analyzer will prompt "Fan/Turb Balance Equipment Setup" as a reminder to verify unit connections. Press ENTER to continue.
Record engine vibration levels at five N1 speeds as follows:

l2item.para: The Analyzer will display CURRENT RPM VALUE. Press ENTER.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS WHEN TRIM BALANCING (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-801). MAINTENANCE MANUAL ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS SUPERSEDE ANY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE ANALYZER PROCEDURE.

l2item.para: At the "Set Engine Speed" prompt, the Analyzer will display the peak vibration N1 speed. Bring the engine to this speed and press ENTER. At the next display, allow 10 to 15 seconds for the phase and amplitude to stabilize, then press ENTER to accept the measuring point.
The ViperCollector/Analyzer will display the next speed (Peak N1 minus 250 rpm). Repeat the procedure for the remaining N1 rpm settings:

note.para: At each speed, make sure that the engine rpm agrees with the speed requested by the ViperCollector/Analyzer and that the phase measurement indicated is fairly stable. If the engine speed changes by ± 50 rpm, press F1 (Reset) to start a new average.

l2item.para: Return the engine to ground idle N1 speed.

note.para: Do not press any key now: the Analyzer will display: "Please wait...Optimizing solution".

l2item.para: At the "Review Prior Run(s) Data" menu, review data taken and press ENTER.

note.para: Use F1 or F5 key to retake one or all speed settings.

l2item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Press F5 to continue.

l1item.para: Wait for the analyzer to produce counterweight optimization result at "Fan/Turb suggested/installed wts" prompt.
Record the position and class of the counterweight hole(s) defined by the Collector/Analyzer (Viper) on the Fan Trim Balancing Data Worksheet (Ref. Fig..
Remove the engine inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-000-801.

note.para: Unbalance is corrected using a maximum of nine counterweight screws.

l1item.para: At the "Fan/Turbine Suggested/Installed Weights" menu, press ENTER. If the trial counterweight is installed in the positions defined by the Viper Collector/Analyzer, press F1, "Inst=Sugg".

If the trim counterweight is installed in a hole other than the defined hole, change the class and location on the ViperCollector/Analyzer using the left/right and up/down curser keys. Record this information.

Install the counterweight screw(s) ( (2), Fig.) on the inlet cone balancing flange location closest to trial solution defined by Viper Collector/Analyzer. Tighten the counterweight screw (2) so that the screw head is flush with or below inlet cone (1) balancing Flange E.
Install the inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-400-805.
After the trial counterweight and the inlet cone have been installed, press ENTER to continue to proceed with the trial five-point ground run.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ANY ENGINE OPERATING LIMIT (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-801). IF ANY N1 SETTING WILL CAUSE THE ENGINE TO EXCEED AN OPERATING LIMIT, OMIT THAT POINT OR POINTS.

l1item.para: Start the engine. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-810.
Let the engine stabilize and the engine oil temperature reach 125°F (51°C) minimum.
Record engine vibration levels at five N1 speeds as follows:

l2item.para: The Analyzer will display CURRENT RPM VALUE. Press ENTER.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-991). MAINTENANCE MANUAL ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS SUPERSEDE ANY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE ANALYZER PROCEDURE.

l2item.para: At the "Set Engine Speed" prompt, the Analyzer will display the peak vibration N1 speed. Bring the engine to this speed and press ENTER. At the next display, allow 10 to 15 seconds for the phase and amplitude to stabilize, then press ENTER to accept the measuring point.
The ViperCollector/Analyzer will display the next speed (Peak N1 minus 250 rpm). Repeat the procedure for the remaining N1 rpm settings:

note.para: At each speed, make sure that the engine rpm agrees with the speed requested by the ViperCollector/Analyzer and that the phase measurement indicated is fairly stable. If the engine speed changes by ± 50 rpm, press F1 (Reset) to start a new average.

l2item.para: Return the engine to ground idle N1 speed.

note.para: Do not press any key now: the Analyzer will display: "Please wait...Optimising solution".

l2item.para: At the "Review Prior Run(s) Data" menu, review data taken and press ENTER.

note.para: Use F1 or F5 key to retake one or all speed settings.

l2item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Press F5 to continue.

l1item.para: Wait for the analyzer to produce counterweight optimization result at "Fan/Turb suggested/installed wts" panel.
If the vibration level is within acceptable limits, end the balance procedure. Record trim counterweight class and screw hole location(s) in the engine log book.
If vibration level is not acceptable, observe and record the new counterweight weight and hole location calculated by ViperCollector/Analyzer, then do the following steps:

note.para: The ViperCollector/Analyzer calculates final or successive solutions based on previous trial counterweights having been removed.

l2item.para: Remove the engine inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-000-801.
Remove the affected trial counterweight screw(s) from the inlet cone. Note the balance hole location number of the removed counterweight (Ref. Fig.).
At the "Fan/Turbine Suggested/Installed Weights" menu, press ENTER. If the trial counterweight is installed in the positions defined by the ViperCollector/Analyzer, press F1, "Inst=Sugg".

If the trim counterweight is installed in a hole other than the defined hole, change the class and location on the Viper Collector/Analyzer using the left/right and up/down curser keys. Record this information.

Install the counterweight screw(s) ( (2),Fig.) on the inlet cone balancing flange location closest to trial solution defined by Viper Collector/Analyzer. Tighten the counterweight screw (2) so that the screw head is flush with or below inlet cone (1) balancing Flange E.
Install the inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-400-805.
After the trial counterweight and the inlet cone have been installed, press ENTER to continue.
Do further trial weight trim balance runs as required.
When engine vibration is within acceptable limits, end the balance procedure. Record trim counterweight class and screw hole location(s) in the engine log book.

Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).
Let engine stabilize and the engine oil temperature reach a minimum of 125°F (51°C).

note.para: If required, run the engine at a higher idle speed to warm the engine oil, then return the power lever to idle.

l1item.para: At the Start Engine menu, press ENTER.

note.para: Please wait while the database is accessing.

l1item.para: From the "Select Condition" menu, use the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the "[ ] ACCEL" condition field. Press ENTER.

note.para: This step will appear if there are multiple conditions to choose from.
There will be a delay of approximately ten seconds while the analyzer prepares the database manager to recover database memory. When the real-time display starts, the analyzer will be recording data.

l1item.para: The ViperCollector/Analyzer will next display real time Plane 1, Plane 3, N1 and N2 engine data on the analyzer screen.

Press the F1 key to answer YES and store the data or press the F5 key to answer NO if the data is to be discarded.
Decelerate the engine to idle speed.
Press F1 again to "End Run" to complete the survey.

task.title: Downloading Transient Vibration Survey and/or Fan Trim Balancing Data to Laptop

l1item.para: Switch power to the Aces Collector analyzer ON.

l1item.para: Disconnect the 10-320-0483analyzer-to-notebook USB data cable.
Turn power to the ViperCollector/Analyzer OFF.
Note the file name and path displayed in the Avtrend software program window in order to find the file for future use.

This task describes how to recover the pointer block 8 or 9 in the DCU when one of these blocks is absent or corrupt on an engine Post-SB66008. It is intended for use by P&WC personnel or other experienced personnel.
This task cannot be used if both blocks 8 and 9 are not healthy (both blocks are absent, or corrupt, or a combination).
This task is to be performed if data is missing from the DCU. A symptom of missing DCU data is if the trend data from the latest flights are not available in GBSLite.
Aircraft must be “ON GROUND” status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: Connect to directly to the DCU as per one of the following methods:

l2item.para: METHOD 1: Connection directly to the Engine DCU using ( PWC40549)cable with external power .

l3item.para: Remove the DCU from the engine.
Connect (PWC40549)cable with external power to the DCU, to a commercial AC wall outlet and to a laptop via a serial port.

l2item.para: METHOD 2: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with DPHM Kit P/N 3074497. (Ref. Fig. 513)

l3item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DPHM Kit P/N 3074497:

l4item.para: Connect DCU ( PWC40712)adapter cable to the DCU.
Connect P36 to Connect DCU (PWC40712)adapter cable.
Connect RS422-USB ( PWC73009)dual channel adapter to (PWC62174)extension cable .
Connect RS422-USB ( PWC73009)dual channel adapter to the laptop.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed.

l3item.para: Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: METHOD 3: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with DCU T-Harness (PWC67792)cable :

l2item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DCU T-Harness Cable, connect (PWC67792) cable to the DCU at P36 and to a laptop via serial port.
Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: Start GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the desktop.
Select the engine program from the drop down menu (PW617F).
Select the TRANSFER MODULE button.
Select DOWNLOAD/UPLOAD button.
In the toolbar, set the connection method to DIRECT.
Under the options menu, select Advanced Options.
When prompted, enter the password "pwc_pwr_user".
Select the "Detect and Recover Unhealthy DCU" button.
If you see one of the following messages, then the recovery was successful.

l2item.para: Block 8 successfully recreated.
Block 8 successfully repaired.
Block 9 successfully recreated.
Block 9 successfully repaired.

l1item.para: If you see one of the following messages contact your P&WC representative:

l2item.para: Program terminated. Invalid software identification.
Program terminated. Block 8 missing and Block 9 corrupted.
Program terminated. Block 9 missing and Block 8 corrupted.
Program terminated. Both Blocks 8 and 9 are missing.
Program terminated. Block 8 corrupted and Block 9 missing.
Program terminated. Block 9 corrupted and Block 8 missing.
Program terminated. Both Blocks 8 and 9 are corrupted.
Blocks 8 and 9 valid. No action taken.

l1item.para: Once a successful recovery is completed. Ensure that the DCU data is as per the logbook by performing Engine Trim Verification Check (Task 71-00-00-760-817).
-If after successfully completing the DCU Pointer Block Recovery, the symptoms are not resolved, contact your P&WC representative.

l1item.para: The Power Plant Cleaning section gives the procedures for engine external wash, fan hand wash, compressor washes (desalination or performance recovery) procedures. Compressor wash system information and water and cleaning solution information is also included.
Definition of Terms:

numlitem.para: Desalination Wash: A procedure that uses water only to remove salt from the engine air path.
Performance Recovery Wash: A procedure that uses the water solution mixed with a cleaning agent to clean the air path of contaminants to attempt to restore performance.
Rinsing: A procedure that uses a water solution to rinse the engine of cleaning solution.
Water Solution: A solution of water with or without isopropyl alcohol.

l1item.para: This task gives the set up information for the compressor wash system.
Not applicable.

entry.para: Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC32677-300)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC64444)

l1item.para: Set up the (PWC32677-300) compressor wash system or the (PWC64444)compressor wash system or the (PWC89888)compressor wash system or a locally manufactured system as shown (Ref. Fig..

note.para: Tubing for interconnection of components is to be 5/16 in. (8 mm) ID minimum.

l1item.para: Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.

task.title: Installation of the Compressor Wash Fixture (PWC69210)

l1item.para: Task Removed.

task.title: Removal of the Compressor Wash Fixture (PWC69210)

l1item.para: Task Removed.
This task gives the procedures for preparing cleaning and rinse solutions for engine washing.
Not applicable.

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

note.para: Demineralized water is recommended for all types of washes. Drinking quality water may be used for engine external, fan and compressor washing (performance recovery).

l1item.para: Obtain a supply of demineralized water or drinking water complying with the requirements shown in Table:

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: The intake filter must not be coarser than 10-microns.

l1item.para: Prepare the water solution (Ref Table).
Performance recovery wash solutions:

l2item.para: B&B TC 100 (PWC11-003E)Detergent Cleaner is a ready-to-use solution. Do not further dilute by adding water and/or methanol

caution.para: DO NOT FURTHER DILUTE SOLUTION BY ADDING WATER AND/OR ANTI-FREEZE SOLUTIONS.

l2item.para: Turco T-5884 (PWC11-001G)Detergent Cleaner can be used but it is not a ready-to-use. Prepare this solution (Ref Table).

note.para: Add 150 ml of (PWC05-005)witconate emulsifying agent and mix solution thoroughly before use to prevent fuel separation.

caution.para: DO NOT FURTHER DILUTE SOLUTION BY ADDING WATER AND/OR ANTI-FREEZE SOLUTIONS.

l2item.para: The Biodegradable Performance Recovery Solutions, Ardrox 6345 ( PWC11-003)Detergent Cleaner or Ardrox 6367 (PWC11-003B)Detergent Cleaner (previously identified as Turboclean 2) can be used but they are not ready-to-use. Prepare this solution (Ref Table).

table.title: Biodegradable Performance Recovery Solutions Ardrox 6345 (PWC11-003) or Ardrox 6367 (PWC11-003B) (previously identified as Turboclean 2)

l1item.para: Table matches required cleaning solutions to the applicable engine cleaning task.
This task gives the procedures for external engine washing.
Not applicable.
The engine should never be left in a contaminated condition overnight, or longer.

caution.para: DO NOT USE GASOLINE OR SIMILAR TOXIC SUBSTANCES FOR EXTERNAL ENGINE CLEANING. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO WASH AN ENGINE THAT IS STILL HOT OR RUNNING. ALLOW ENGINE TO COOL FOR A MINIMUM PERIOD OF 40 MINUTES AFTER SHUTDOWN TO PREVENT PRECIPITATION FROM INADVERTENT USE OF HARD WATER.

l1item.para: External washing with fresh water is recommended when engine is contaminated with salt, volcanic dust or corrosive chemicals such as those found in industrial smog. Demineralized water is not necessary. (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-804 for water quality requirements)
Mask all electrical connectors with plastic wrap to avoid moisture damage to connectors.
Wash the engine by hand using a clean sponge or soft cloth.

If a water wash is ineffective, a (PWC11-027) petroleum solvent /water emulsion may be used to remove oil, grime, or other materials/fluids (e.g. hydraulic fluids). Thoroughly rinse with water to remove all traces of cleaning fluid. Completely dry the engine using clean, dry compressed air.

note.para: External cleaning is very effective in tracing possible origin of external oil leakage.

l1item.para: Remove the plastic wrap from the electrical connectors.
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for hand washing the fan.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

warning.para: PRIOR TO FAN WASHING MAKE SURE THE STARTER SWITCH AND IGNITION SYSTEM ARE IN THE OFF POSITION AND THE THRUST LEVER IS IN THE CUT OFF POSITION.
WHEN WASHING THE FAN BY HAND WEAR RUBBER GLOVES AND USE CAUTION AS THE LEADING EDGE OF FAN BLADES MAY BE VERY SHARP.

l1item.para: Fan blade washing is done by hand using a sponge or soft clean cloth.
Each blade must be washed individually on both pressure and suction side.
Wash the fan with desalination solution. Refer to Task 71-00-00-160-804.
Rinse with desalination solution.
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for doing a compressor desalination wash.
Deleted.
Deleted.
Place suitable containers or a drip pan under the engine.

caution.para: FAILURE TO BLANK THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) OR TO REMOVE THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WILL RESULT IN CONTAMINATION OF THE AGB ENGINE OIL BY WASH FLUID.

l1item.para: Prepare the engine to prevent wash fluid from entering the AGB:

l2item.para: Install either a (PWC69812) blanking plug (1) or a PK3654-49 cap (1) or equivalent in the AGB breather port (2).
As an alternate to step (a), remove the AGB breather tube (3). (Ref. Task 72-60-02-000-801)
Make sure the engine control panel switch is set to the OFF position.
Make sure the engine thrust lever is in the IDLE position.
Shut off the aircraft cabin bleed air system. Refer to the AMM.
Make sure the engine ignition system is OFF.

entry.para: Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC32677-300)
Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Cap, AGB Breather Port (Alternate to PWC69812)

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT THE ENGINE TEMPERATURE IS LESS THAN 150°F (65°C). IF THE TEMPERATURE IS HIGHER, HARD WATER CAN CAUSE MINERAL CONTAMINATION.
DO NOT EXCEED WASH OR RINSE FLUID INJECTION RATES.
THE (PWC69836)WASH WAND (5) MUST BE USED WITH FOUR (PWC66581) WEDGES (4) TO PREVENT FAN ROTATION DURING MOTORING CYCLES.
THE LP COMPRESSOR IS A TITANIUM PART. OPERATE THE WASH WAND WITH CARE.

l1item.para: Connect the (PWC69836)wash wand to the (PWC32677-300) mobile wash system or the (PWC64444)portable wash system or the (PWC89888)portable wash system or a locally manufactured wash system.
Install (PWC66581)wedges (4) as follows:

caution.para: MAKE SURE WEDGES ARE IN GOOD CONDITION.

l2item.para: Inspect wedges (4) for damage prior to installation to prevent damage to the abraidable material on the fan case. Replace any broken wedges.
Install four (PWC66581)wedges (4) between the tips of four equally-spaced fan blades and the fan case to prevent fan rotation. Make sure the wedges are secure.

caution.para: USE ONLY DEMINERALIZED WATER IN SOLUTIONS USED TO DO COMPRESSOR DESALINATION WASH FOR ENGINES EXPOSED TO CHEMICAL FIRE EXTINGUISHING AGENTS.

l1item.para: Fill the wash system with the required water solution:

l2item.para: Pressurize the wash system.
Adjust the wash system pressure to obtain a flow rate of 1.6 US gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Use water solution for a compressor desalination wash. Refer to Task 71-00-00-160-804.

caution.para: INSTALL THE WASH WAND GENTLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN BLADES, FAN STATOR AND THE CORE INTAKE STRUTS.
MAKE SURE THAT THE WASH WAND DISK (6) IS SITTING ON THE TOP OF THE NOSE CONE AND AGAINST THE FAN BLADES.
MAKE SURE THAT THE NOZZLE OF THE WASH WAND IS POINTED INTO THE HP COMPRESSOR INTAKE.

l1item.para: Insert the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) by rotating the wand nozzle (7) through the fan blades, fan stator and the core intake struts into position in the HP compressor intake.
Make sure the four (PWC66581) wedges (4) prevent the fan from rotating.
Hold the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) during the engine motoring to make sure the disk (6) stays flat against the fan blades and sitting on the nose cone.

caution.para: DO NOT OPERATE THE WASH SYSTEM IF EITHER THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) IS NOT CAPPED OR IF THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WAS NOT REMOVED.
BEFORE MOTORING ENGINE, MAKE SURE THE ENGINE INTAKE IS CLEAR OF ALL LOOSE OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE INGESTED AND CAUSE ENGINE DAMAGE AND SUBSEQUENT FAILURE.
OBSERVE THE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: Do two 20 second dry motoring runs using the engine starter. As N2 rotation passes 5%, start injection of 0.8 US gallons (3 liters) of the water solution into the engine core at a rate of 1.6 gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Stop motoring after 20 seconds. Turn the wash system off when N2 rotation is less than 5%.

caution.para: PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN STATOR VANES AND FAN BLADES BY GENTLY ROTATING THE WAND (5) AS IT IS REMOVED.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) from engine.
Remove the four (PWC66581) wedges (4).

caution.para: DELETED.
ALLOW STARTER TO COOL BETWEEN RUNS (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: If isopropyl alcohol was used in the water solution, do a 20 second dry motoring run.

note.para: DELETED.

l1item.para: Disassemble wash system and (PWC69836) wash wand (3).
Deleted.
Deleted.
Deleted.

caution.para: MAKE SURE ALL CLEANING EQUIPMENT HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM THE ENGINE INLET.

l1item.para: Remove either the (PWC69812)blanking plug (1) or the cap PK3654-49 (1) from the AGB breather outlet port (2) if either were installed. Discard the cap.
Install the AGB breather tube (3) if it was removed. (Ref. Task 72-60-02-400-801)
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Select CABIN BLEED OFF.
Do an engine start and operate the engine for one minute at 80% N1 to dry the engine.
Reduce power to IDLE. Operate the engine for five minutes at IDLE with CABIN BLEED ON.
Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for doing a compressor performance recovery wash.
Disconnect the two aircraft P3 air bleed tubes. Refer to the AMM.
Secure a plastic bag over the two exposed aircraft P3 ports. Leave the two engine P3 bleed ports open.
Place suitable containers or a drip pan under the engine.

caution.para: FAILURE TO BLANK THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) OR TO REMOVE THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WILL RESULT IN CONTAMINATION OF THE AGB ENGINE OIL BY WASH FLUID

l1item.para: Prepare the engine to prevent wash fluid from entering the AGB:

l2item.para: Install either a (PWC69812) blanking plug (1) or a PK3654-49 cap (1) or equivalent in the AGB breather port (2).
As an alternate to step (a), remove the AGB breather tube (3). (Ref. Task 72-60-02-000-801)
Make sure the engine control panel switch is set to the OFF position.
Make sure the engine thrust lever is in the IDLE position.
Shut off the aircraft cabin bleed air system. Refer to the AMM.
Make sure the engine ignition system is OFF.

entry.para: Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC32677-300)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC64444)

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

entry.para: Cap, AGB Breather Port (Alternate to PWC69812)

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT THE ENGINE TEMPERATURE IS LESS THAN 150°F (65°C). IF THE TEMPERATURE IS HIGHER, HARD WATER CAN CAUSE MINERAL CONTAMINATION.
DO NOT EXCEED WASH OR RINSE FLUID INJECTION RATES.
THE (PWC69836)WASH WAND (5) MUST BE USED WITH FOUR (PWC66581) WEDGES (4) TO PREVENT FAN ROTATION DURING MOTORING CYCLES.
THE LP COMPRESSOR IS A TITANIUM PART. OPERATE THE WASH WAND WITH CARE.

l1item.para: Connect the (PWC69836)wash wand to the (PWC32677-300) mobile wash system or (PWC64444) portable wash system or the (PWC89888)portable wash system or a locally manufactured wash system.
Install (PWC66581)wedges (4) as follows:

caution.para: MAKE SURE WEDGES ARE IN GOOD CONDITION.

l2item.para: Inspect wedges (4) for damage prior to installation to prevent damage to the abraidable material on the fan case. Replace any broken wedges.
Install four (PWC66581)wedges (4) between the tips of four equally-spaced fan blades and the fan case to prevent fan rotation. Make sure the wedges are secure.

caution.para: DO NOT DO A COMPRESSOR PERFORMANCE RECOVERY WASH OF ENGINES EXPOSED TO CHEMICAL FIRE EXTINGUISHING AGENTS.

l1item.para: Fill the wash system with the required compressor wash fluid:

l2item.para: Pressurize the wash system.
Adjust the wash system pressure to obtain a flow rate of 1.6 US gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Use (PWC11-001G)detergent cleaner, (PWC11-003)detergent cleaner, (PWC11-003B) detergent cleaner or (PWC11-003E) detergent cleaner for a performance recovery wash.

caution.para: INSTALL THE WASH WAND GENTLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN BLADES, FAN STATOR AND THE CORE INTAKE STRUTS.
MAKE SURE THAT THE WASH WAND DISK (6) IS SITTING ON THE TOP OF THE NOSE CONE AND IS flat against THE FAN BLADES AFTER WAND INSTALLATION.
MAKE SURE THAT THE NOZZLE (7) OF THE WASH WAND (5) IS POINTED INTO THE HP COMPRESSOR INTAKE BEFORE APPLYING PRESSURE.

l1item.para: Insert the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) by rotating the wand nozzle (7) through the fan blades, fan stator and the core intake struts into position in the HP compressor intake.
Make sure the four (PWC66581) wedges (4) prevent the fan from rotating.
Hold the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) during the engine motoring to make sure the disk (6) stays flat against the fan blades and sitting on the nose cone.

caution.para: DO NOT OPERATE THE WASH SYSTEM IF EITHER THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) IS NOT CAPPED OR IF THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WAS NOT REMOVED.
BEFORE MOTORING ENGINE, MAKE SURE THE ENGINE INTAKE IS CLEAR OF ALL LOOSE OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE INGESTED AND CAUSE ENGINE DAMAGE AND SUBSEQUENT FAILURE.
OBSERVE THE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: Start a 20 second dry motoring runs using the engine starter. As N2 rotation passes 5%, start injection of 0.8 US gallons (3 liters) of the cleaning solution into the engine HP compressor gas path at a rate of 1.6 gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Stop motoring after 20 seconds. Turn the wash system off when N2 rotation is less than 5%.
Allow cleaning solution to soak for 30 minutes.

Start a 20 second dry motoring run using the engine starter. As N2 rotation passes 5%, start injection of 0.8 US gallons (3 liters) of water solution into the engine core at a rate of 1.6 gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Stop motoring after 20 seconds. Turn the wash system off when N2 rotation is less than 5%.
If evidence of cleaning solution is still present inside the engine, repeat steps (9) and (10).

caution.para: PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN STATOR VANES AND FAN BLADES BY GENTLY ROTATING THE WAND (5) AS IT IS REMOVED.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) from engine.
Remove the four (PWC66581) wedges (4).

caution.para: OBSERVE THE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).
ALLOW THE STARTER TO COOL BETWEEN RUNS (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: Do a 20 second dry motoring run.

note.para: If ambient temperatures required the use of isopropyl alcohol in the water solution, do an additional 20 second dry motoring run to purge the engine of remaining fumes.

l1item.para: If required, do another performance recovery wash after engine drying.
Dissassemble wash system and (PWC69836) wash wand (5).
Remove the plastic bags from the two aircraft P3 bleed ports.
Check the P3 air ports for moisture. Remove moisture.
Connect the two P3 air bleed lines. Refer to the AMM.

caution.para: MAKE SURE ALL CLEANING EQUIPMENT HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM THE ENGINE INLET.

l1item.para: Remove either the (PWC69812)blanking plug (1) or the cap PK3654-49 (1) from the AGB breather outlet port (2) if either were installed. Discard the cap.
Install the AGB breather tube (3) if it was removed. (Ref. Task 72-60-02-400-801)
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Select CABIN BLEED OFF.
Do an engine start and operate the engine for one minute at 80% N1 to dry the engine.
Reduce power to IDLE.
Select CABIN BLEED ON and operate the engine for five minutes at IDLE.
Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
If required, do another performance recovery wash after engine drying.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
